thread.title: The Morning Risk Report: First Winner Under U.S. Bribery Policy

author: Henry Cutter
title: The Morning Risk Report: First Winner Under U.S. Bribery Policy
text:

U.S. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, shown in March, unveiled the FCPA Corporate Enforcement Policy in November. Reuters Good morning. Dun & Bradstreet is the first company to avoid criminal charges under a months-old U.S. Justice Department policy meant to encourage companies to turn in themselves for bribery. The firm will pay $9.2 million to securities regulators.
The Securities and Exchange Commission found two indirect Dun & Bradstreet subsidiaries in China made unlawful payments to win or keep business from 2006 through 2012. It said the illegal payments weren’t properly recorded in the company’s books and the company’s accounting controls were too weak to detect the problem.
“Based upon the information known to the Department at this time, we have declined prosecution consistent with the FCPA Corporate Enforcement Policy,” the DOJ said in a letter Monday to a lawyer for the business-data company. “We have reached this conclusion despite the bribery committed by company’s subsidiaries in China.”
The policy announced in late November by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein builds on a pilot program that began in early 2016. It includes a “presumption” prosecutors won’t act against companies that voluntarily disclose their wrongdoing, cooperate with investigators and take the steps needed to prevent a recurrence. The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act bars companies from bribing foreign officials to win or keep a business advantage.
The Justice Department in its letter noted Dun & Bradstreet voluntarily disclosed the matter, cooperated with the investigation and worked to improve its compliance program and accounting systems.
Dun & Bradstreet terminated 11 people involved in the misconduct, disciplined others and will pay the SEC “the full amount of disgorgement” determined by the securities regulator. The SEC said the company will pay $6.1 million of profit gained via its misconduct, interest of $1.1 million and a penalty of $2 million, bringing the total to $9.2 million.
Dun & Bradstreet didn’t admit or deny wrongdoing. The company confirmed it resolved matters with the SEC and said it takes seriously its obligation to run its business legally and responsibly.
COMPLIANCE
U.S. curbs human-rights cases vs. companies. The Supreme Court limited foreign victims of terrorism, torture and other international crimes in their use of U.S. courts to sue corporations they say helped perpetrate abuses, ruling that a centuries-old statute at the heart of major human-rights cases could be employed only against individuals, the WSJ reports.
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled 5-4 to limit the use of the Alien Torts Statute against corporations. PHOTO: ERIC THAYER/REUTERS Top U.S. court backs challenges to patents. The Supreme Court upheld a new government process for challenging the validity of patents, cementing a method that technology companies and other businesses have used to knock out patent protections for more than a thousand claimed inventions, the WSJ reports.
Federal judge rules in favor of DACA. A third federal judge ruled against efforts to cancel Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, which protects undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. The ruling requires the U.S. to accept new applications under the program, but gives the Trump administration 90 days to explain its decision to close DACA, the WSJ reports.
U.S. FDA goes after e-cigarette maker. The Food and Drug Administration said it is moving against the sale of e-cigarettes to minors by targeting Juul Labs Inc. , the maker of one of the most popular such products in the U.S. The company said it agrees that illegal sales to minors are unacceptable, the WSJ reports.
Sinclair to sell TV stations in push for Tribune deal. Sinclair Broadcast Group has reached deals to sell nearly two dozen television stations as it works to get regulators to sign off on its $3.9 billion purchase of Tribune Media Some stations are owned by Sinclair and some by Tribune, the WSJ reports.
DATA SECURITY
Yahoo’s successor to pay over breach. Yahoo Inc.’s response to a 2014 hack of hundreds of millions of user accounts drew a fine from regulators, the first time a public company has been penalized over its handling of a cybersecurity breach. Altaba Inc. , Yahoo successor firm, will pay $35 million, the WSJ reports.
FDA plans security ‘go-team’ for medical devices. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is pushing for improved cybersecurity for medical devices that can be vulnerable to attack. The FDA plans to set up a “go-team” to investigate suspected incidents of compromise in a field where such lapses can have potentially deadly consequences, the WSJ reports.
GOVERNANCE
Europe’s mandates give women board seats. Diversity advocates have long argued in business terms for women in high-ranking roles. Now blunt-force measures appear to be moving the needle. The U.S., once the leader in female directors, is lagging Europe where mandates have forced corporations to boost the ratio of women holding board seats, the WSJ reports.
RISK
Pyongyang’s nuclear test site is badly damaged. Much of North Korea’s underground nuclear test facility is unusable due to the collapse of a cavity inside the mountain after the latest detonation, according to a soon-to-be-published study. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said Saturday he is closing the facility, a move welcomed by the U.S., South Korea and China, the WSJ reports.
U.S. EPA proposes shift on rules. The Environmental Protection Agency plans to restrict research used in developing regulations, a change that could affect rules governing everything from household products to power-plant emissions. A proposal would exclude studies that don’t make their raw data public, the WSJ reports.
CFPB weighs ending access to complaints on banks. The U.S. is likely to end public access to a web portal used by consumers to file complaints against financial firms. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s acting director, Mick Mulvaney, on Tuesday said the complaint database contains information that hasn’t been fully vetted by the government, the WSJ reports.
STRATEGY
Comcast formalizes bid for Sky. Comcast formally submitted its $31 billion proposal to buy the pay-TV operator Sky PLC , one of several deals it has contemplated that could transform its business and roil its rivals. The offer tops one by 21st Century Fo x, which owns 39% of Sky, the WSJ reports.
Comcast continues to lose cable TV subscribers. PHOTO: JOY ASICO/ASSOCIATED PRESS Globalstar, Fiberlight, to merge. Satellite provider Globalstar plans to merge with landline operator FiberLight LLC in a $1.65 billion deal, a bid to put the unprofitable satellite company on firmer footing as it chases new customers. The deal would combine the firms with assets of Thermo, an investment firm. Investor Jay Monroe controls all three companies, the WSJ reports.
Shire opens door to Takeda deal. Takeda Pharmaceutical moved closer to securing a $64 billion takeover of Shire PLC after the target said it was willing to recommend that shareholders accept the Japanese firm’s latest proposal and extended a deadline to reach a definitive agreement, the WSJ reports.
